National Semiconductor dropped 4.9 per cent to $22.71 after Lehman Brothers cut its rating on the stock from “overweight” to “equal weight”.Chemicals and construction company Ashland dipped after it said it had agreed to sell its highway construction business to Irish construction group CRH for $1.3bn. Some investors had forecast a better price for the sale and shares fell 5.7 per cent to $62.55.Discount retailer Dollar General dropped 9.6 per cent to a three-year low of $12.74 after it lowered its earnings guidance for its fiscal second quarter.

Titular: Higher fuel prices add to cost of hurricane damage
Texto: US businesses continued efforts to assess the damage to their regional facilities in hurricane-affected states on Thursday and to gauge the likely impact of higher US petrol prices on their national operations.Major retailers, including Wal-Mart, Target and Federated Department Stores, warned that store closures in the region were likely to depress sales this month, while high fuel prices as the result of shortages are likely to increase pressure on low- income consumers in particular.Dollar General, the hard discounter which that operates more than 7,000 stores across the US targeted at low- income consumers, said it believed that some that 200 of its stores in the region were still closed, mostly as the result of power cuts.“Some of these stores may have been permanently destroyed, although the company is not yet in a position to make that determination,” the company said on Thursday.Hotels groups were largely focused on getting in touch with employees and locating guests at properties in the affected areas.But early signs indicated a similar pattern seen in Florida last year when hotel rooms filled with evacuees and emergency workers in the wake of four hurricanes that pounded the state.InterContinental Hotels, the owner of the Holiday Inn brand, said about a dozen hotels in New Orleans were hit by Katrina.However, nearby hotels outside the affected area in cities such as Shreveport, Louisiana, Memphis, Tennessee, Pensacola, Florida and Jackson, Mississippi were fully booked.Cendant, the owner of the Days Inn and Ramada brands, also reported that evacuees were filling hotel rooms in surrounding states. Its reservations centre was working with FEMA to identify vacancies and book rooms for emergency and utility workers travelling to the affected region.Hilton Hotels dispatched 45 buses to evacuate 1,600 employees and guests from downtown New Orleans and to take them to hotels in Austin, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio.Marc Falcone, lodging analyst with Deutsche Bank, wrote in a research report: “If these large hotels are able to escape significant damage, we believe it is possible that they could experience a surge in demand for rooms from displaced residents and FEMA emergency officials.”Analysts also warned of the impact on telecommunications companies. Analysts at CIBC estimated that BellSouth, with 1.75m customers without any phone service, will incur expenses of about $300m and forgo revenue of about $150m.However, shares of house builders and other companies seen as likely to benefit from reconstruction efforts climbed on Thursday, including Cemex, LaFarge and Caterpillar.Many big US airlines were on Thursday ferrying extra fuel to likely bottlenecks, including destinations in Florida, which relies on barge traffic from the Gulf Coast for much of its jet fuel supply.The Federal Aviation Administration on Thursday said current information indicated that airports and airlines have enough jet fuel to support continued full commercial operations, Reuters reports. Roger King, analyst at CreditSights, said: “It could take a week or two before [extra fuel] supplies can be shipped in from Europe or south-east Asia, but it is a good bet that an armada full of gasoline and jet fuel is heading this way.”Analysts said the financial impact of higher jet fuel prices would be far more damaging for the airlines than regional fuel shortages.Reporting by Kevin Allison, Amy Yee and Jonathan Birchall in New York and Kevin Allison in New York
